comments:
The following NPE happened when a plugin was replaced with a new version that 
removed the hardcoded bundle manifest.  I assume this is causing the manifest 
timestamp checker to fail because it does not find the original manifest that 
it is expecting.

!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Feb 13, 2004 11:09:42.141
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at 
org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseBundleData.checkManifestTimeStamp
(EclipseBundleData.java:96)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseBundleData.initializeExistingBundle
(EclipseBundleData.java:83)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseAdaptor.getInstalledBundles
(EclipseAdaptor.java:286)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Framework.initialize
(Framework.java:173)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Framework.<init>
(Framework.java:97)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.OSGi.createFramework
(OSGi.java:90)
	at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.OSGi.<init>(OSGi.java:31)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run
(EclipseStarter.java:86)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:279)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:742)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:581)

!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------

I'm seeing this bug on start-up, and it is preventing Eclipse from starting.  
Deleting "~/.eclipse" allows Eclipse to start with no exception.  
I200402190800.
*** Bug 52540 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

That is right, we were assuming that something that we new as a real bundle
would always have a bundle manifest. 

But that does not explain why users are getting that for the first time they run
the new install. Doug/Alvin: were you guys playing with removing bundle
manifests from bundles? Or it just happened at the first time you run the new
install?

err...when i did my 'new install' i forgot to remove the '.eclipse' dir; just
removed the workspace dir. hard to keep track of where everything is being moved
around to. :P

removing the directory made things work here.

Ok, I forgot the non-writable install location case, where the configuration
area ends up in the user home dir and may be by multiple installs.

You shouldn't have to delete anything, Alvin. Things went wrong because we have
a bug in this area.
